payload.name: negotiation-coalition
payload.core: Reason about acceptable agreements and coalition formation under constraints and asymmetric information. Focus on reaching mutually beneficial outcomes, not just predicting equilibria. Key insight: negotiation is joint problem-solving, not zero-sum combat.

out.valid: within ZOPA, respects constraints, Pareto-improving over BATNA
monotonic toward agreement zone, reciprocity maintained
stable (no blocking coalition via Shapley or core test)
no party worse off vs BATNA, gains distributed per contribution
BATNA-bounded for all parties, ZOPA >0 or proven empty

proc: 1. MAP PARTIES: list all stakeholders including hidden veto players and affected non-participants
2. SEPARATE POSITIONS FROM INTERESTS: stated demands vs underlying needs (ask 'why' 5 times)
3. CALCULATE BATNAs: each party's best alternative if no deal; this sets reservation prices
4. FIND ZOPA: overlap of reservation prices; if empty, either expand pie or acknowledge no deal
5. ASSESS INFORMATION: what does each party know? what signals can reveal/conceal?
6. GENERATE OPTIONS: brainstorm integrative solutions that create value before claiming it
7. EVALUATE TRADEOFFS: which issues are high-value to them but low-cost to you (and vice versa)?
8. SEQUENCE CONCESSIONS: start with easy wins, build momentum, reciprocate to establish trust
9. TEST COALITION STABILITY: can any subgroup improve by defecting? use Shapley value for fair splits
10. FORMALIZE: write agreement with enforcement (escrow, reputation, legal), exit clauses, review dates

decision_points.distributive_vs_integrative: Use distributive (claim value) when: fixed pie proven, one-shot interaction, BATNA strong. Use integrative (create value) when: multiple issues tradeable, ongoing relationship, information asymmetry exploitable through disclosure.
decision_points.anchor_or_wait: Anchor first when: your prep is strong, their BATNA is weak, range uncertainty benefits you. Wait when: information asymmetry favors learning, relationship is nascent, their anchor reveals constraints.
decision_points.walk_away_test: Walk away when: best offer < BATNA, trust is broken, implementation risk exceeds value, relationship cost exceeds deal value.

quick_checklist: [ ] All parties with veto power identified?
[ ] BATNA calculated for self (not hoped-for outcome)?
[ ] BATNA estimated for counterparty (validated if possible)?
[ ] Interests vs positions distinguished for all parties?
[ ] Tradeoff matrix built (issue x party value)?
[ ] Agreement includes enforcement and renegotiation terms?
[ ] Relationship impact on future interactions assessed?
check: all stakeholders identified including hidden influencers
BATNAs estimated with evidence (not wishful thinking)
ZOPA calculated numerically or proven empty
interests vs positions distinguished for each party
coalition stability verified via blocking-coalition test
relationship NPV included in payoff calculation

diff.game-theoretic: GT predicts equilibria from payoffs; negotiation seeks agreement through process, norms, and relationship. Use GT to prep (model counterparty), use negotiation to execute (build deal).
diff.theory-of-mind: ToM infers beliefs and intentions; negotiation applies those inferences to craft acceptable offers. ToM is diagnostic; negotiation is prescriptive.
diff.mechanism-design: MD designs rules ex ante (auctions, voting); negotiation operates within existing rules or informal settings. MD is architect; negotiation is player.
diff.rhetorical: rhetoric persuades audience to adopt belief; negotiation trades concessions for mutual gain. Rhetoric is one-way influence; negotiation is two-way exchange.
diff.mcda: MCDA evaluates alternatives against criteria; negotiation involves strategic counterparties who adapt. MCDA assumes fixed options; negotiation creates them.

common_confusions.symptom: modeling negotiation as pure equilibrium prediction, ignoring relationship and process
common_confusions.resolution: GT informs prep (payoff analysis); negotiation adds trust-building, creative option generation, implementation planning

common_confusions.symptom: trying to persuade counterparty instead of finding mutually acceptable trade
common_confusions.resolution: rhetoric changes minds; negotiation exchanges value. If counterparty won't move, generate new options rather than pushing harder

common_confusions.symptom: designing the negotiation process when you should be participating in it
common_confusions.resolution: MD requires authority to set rules; negotiation works within given constraints. Use MD when you control the process, negotiation when you're a participant

fail.mode: winning the negotiation but losing the relationship and long-term incentives
signals: counterparty disengages or retaliates in future dealings
reputation damage visible in network (fewer incoming deals)
pattern of short-term gains followed by long-term losses
coalition partners defect at first opportunity

mit.strategy: include relationship NPV in payoff function
mit.test: calculate: would I accept this deal if roles reversed? if no, relationship cost exceeds apparent gain
scenario-plan: if market shifts 20%, does agreement still hold? if counterparty gets better offer, do they honor commitment?

mit.strategy: model as repeated game, not one-shot
mit.test: calculate shadow of the future: probability of future interaction x value of future deals > short-term extraction gain?
agreement includes explicit clauses: 'if X changes by Y%, parties reconvene to adjust terms'
for each possible subcoalition, calculate: can they improve by excluding others? if yes, unstable

anti_patterns.name: positional bargaining
anti_patterns.desc: anchoring on positions rather than exploring interests; leads to impasse or suboptimal deals
anti_patterns.fix: ask 'why is that important?' to uncover underlying interests

anti_patterns.name: winner's curse
anti_patterns.desc: counterparty accepts too quickly, signaling you left value on table
anti_patterns.fix: slow down, explore why they agreed; consider whether you missed something

anti_patterns.name: BATNA bluffing
anti_patterns.desc: overstating walkaway option; damages trust when called
anti_patterns.fix: know your true BATNA; signal strength through confidence, not false claims

anti_patterns.name: coalition instability blindness
anti_patterns.desc: ignoring that subgroups may defect post-agreement
anti_patterns.fix: test each possible subcoalition for profitable deviation before finalizing

use: partnerships and joint ventures (equity splits, governance)

ex.problem: Two teams need shared infrastructure budget; total available less than combined asks
parties: Team A (needs compute for ML training)
Team B (needs storage for data lake)

step_1_interests.A_interest: run ML training jobs within 2-week cycle time
step_1_interests.B_interest: store 18 months of data for compliance and analytics

step_2_batnas.A: use legacy on-prem cluster (slower, 4-week cycle time, $0 new spend)
step_2_batnas.B: defer data lake 6 months, delete data >6 months ($0 new spend, compliance risk)

ex.step_3_zopa: total budget $120k; combined asks $180k; ZOPA exists if prioritized spend < $120k
step_4_integrative_options: time-share compute: A uses nights/weekends, B uses business hours
tiered storage: hot tier for recent data, cold archive for compliance
spot instances for non-urgent ML jobs (50% cost reduction)
ex.step_6_coalition_test: neither team gains by escalating to VP alone (VP will impose 50/50 split worse for both)

agreement.renegotiation: if either team's project scope changes >25%, reconvene
agreement.relationship: joint presentation to VP on cost savings builds shared credibility

micro_example.situation: You're negotiating salary for a new role. Offered $150k, you want $175k.
micro_example.batna: current job at $140k with promotion path
micro_example.integrative_move: trade salary for signing bonus, equity, or start date flexibility
micro_example.test: if they accept $175k instantly, you left money on table (winner's curse)
micro_example.agreement: $165k + $10k signing bonus + 1 week earlier start (total value ~$177k)
